articles.headline: Obama Urges Congress to Act to Stave Off Cuts
articles.snippet: President Obama pressed lawmakers on Tuesday to pass a package of limited spending cuts and tax changes to avoid the across-the-board reductions set to take effect on March 1.
articles.abstract: President Obama pressed lawmakers on Tuesday to pass a package of limited spending cuts and tax changes to avoid the across-the-board reductions set to take effect on March 1.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Tuesday called on Congress to quickly pass a new package of limited spending cuts and tax increases to head off substantial across-the-board reductions to domestic and military spending set to begin on March 1, but his appeal for more revenue was dismissed by Republicans.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Jackie Calmes

articles.headline: S.& P. E-Mails on Mortgage Crisis Show Alarm and Gallows Humor
articles.snippet: In 2006, some executives at Standard & Poor’s pushed to revise the firm’s rating models in hopes of preserving market share, while others expressed deep concerns about the poor performance of the securities, according to court documents. The credi...
articles.abstract: In 2006, some executives at Standard & Poor’s pushed to revise the firm’s rating models in hopes of preserving market share, while others expressed deep concerns about the poor performance of the securities, according to court documents. The credit rating agency has called the suit “meritless.”
articles.byline: By Mary Williams Walsh and Ron Nixon

articles.headline: Zynga at a Crossroads in Mobile Quest
articles.snippet: As its revenue remains flat, the social-game creator faces the test of successfully putting its most popular Web games, starting with Farmville, on mobile devices.
articles.abstract: As its revenue remains flat, the social-game creator faces the test of successfully putting its most popular Web games, starting with Farmville, on mobile devices.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Zynga has been on a monumental losing streak. Hits have been rare, profits nonexistent and crucial employees are fleeing.

articles.headline: Health Insurance Companies Get in Shape for 2014
articles.snippet: After years of marketing plans to employers, not individual consumers, health insurers are making radical changes because of the Affordable Care Act.
articles.abstract: After years of marketing plans to employers, not individual consumers, health insurers are making radical changes because of the Affordable Care Act.
articles.lead_paragraph: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — Since Patrick J. Geraghty arrived here a year and a half ago to lead the state’s largest health insurer, Florida Blue, he has expanded its operations in Medicare and Medicaid, entered arrangements with hospitals and doctors, bought a medical group, and dabbled with a new private sector marketplace that allows employees to choose plans from different insurance companies.

articles.headline: Immigration Reform Issue: The Effect on the Budget
articles.snippet: Some obstacles may have been overcome, but reform will probably be opposed by those who will view it as a potentially large expansion of welfare.
articles.abstract: Some obstacles may have been overcome, but reform will probably be opposed by those who will view it as a potentially large expansion of welfare.
articles.lead_paragraph: The stars could hardly have shone brighter on the prospects for immigration reform than in the early months of 2007.

articles.headline: Debevoise & Plimpton Drops Trusts and Estates Practice
articles.snippet: The law firm’s move to get out of the estate-planning business comes as the legal industry continues to emphasize more profitable practices.
articles.abstract: The law firm’s move to get out of the estate-planning business comes as the legal industry continues to emphasize more profitable practices.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last month, the nation’s leading trusts and estates lawyers convened at a Florida resort to discuss the latest in estate planning.

articles.headline: Drone Strikes’ Risks to Get Rare Moment in the Public Eye
articles.snippet: The chief architect of a clandestine campaign of targeted killings, John O. Brennan, will face a Senate confirmation hearing as President Obama’s nominee for C.I.A. director.
articles.abstract: The chief architect of a clandestine campaign of targeted killings, John O. Brennan, will face a Senate confirmation hearing as President Obama’s nominee for C.I.A. director.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — Late last August, a 40-year-old cleric named Salem Ahmed bin Ali Jaber stood up to deliver a speech denouncing Al Qaeda in a village mosque in far eastern Yemen.
articles.byline: By Robert F. Worth, Mark Mazzetti and Scott Shane

articles.headline: Cairo Activist Fighting Tear Gas With Tear Gas
articles.snippet: Two years after President Hosni Mubarak fell, Egyptian street activists like Mohamed Mokbel say they are still fighting for the democratic goals of the Arab Spring revolt.
articles.abstract: Two years after President Hosni Mubarak fell, Egyptian street activists like Mohamed Mokbel say they are still fighting for the democratic goals of the Arab Spring revolt.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — As hundreds fled the advancing armored cars of riot police officers, Mohamed Mokbel ran forward.

articles.headline: It’s a Tablet. No, It’s a PC. Surface Pro Is Both.
articles.snippet: Microsoft introduces the Surface Pro, a tablet with features that transform it into a PC. But there are some disappointments.
articles.abstract: Microsoft introduces the Surface Pro, a tablet with features that transform it into a PC. But there are some disappointments.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, Microsoft has subsisted on the milk of its two cash cows: Windows and Office. The company’s occasional ventures into hardware generally haven’t ended well: *cough* Zune, Kin Phone, Spot Watch *cough*.

articles.headline: Guilty Plea and Big Fine for Bank in Rate Case
articles.snippet: The Royal Bank of Scotland on Wednesday reached a combined $612 million settlement with American and British authorities over accusations that it manipulated interest rates, the latest case to emerge from a broad international investigation.
articles.abstract: The Royal Bank of Scotland on Wednesday reached a combined $612 million settlement with American and British authorities over accusations that it manipulated interest rates, the latest case to emerge from a broad international investigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: A campaign to root out financial fraud secured a victory on Wednesday, as authorities took aim at the Royal Bank of Scotland for its role in an interest rate manipulation scheme that has emboldened prosecutors and consumed the banking industry.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Mark Scott
